text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Sunday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- An adventurous Kenyan confidence trickster is on the prowl in his home country.
- Uganda's ban on the importation of powdered milk from Kenya still stands.
- An Australian pilot recently released from detention in Somalia believes he is lucky to be alive.
- Uganda threatens to disconnect the electricity supply to Kenya if tariffs are not revised in line with current prices.
- Kenya's National Union of Teachers backs sit-in by Nairobi teachers to protest non-payment of their September salaries.
- Some members of the Law Society of Kenya call for the resignation of their chairman.
- President Daniel arap Moi rules out the idea of tribal spokesmen, saying problems know no ethnic boundaries.
- Minister for education exposes a syndicate by coffee and tea weighing clerks in Murang'a district who collude with wealthy individuals to steal farmers' produce.
- A Machakos tycoon storms a hotel in the town and threatens to kill the municipal council clerk over land ownership.
